Haywood immediately became active in the WFM, and by 1900 he had become a member of the national union's General Executive Board. In 1902, he assumed co-leadership of the WFM with [[Charles Moyer]]. That year, the WFM became involved in the [[Ludlow massacre|Colorado Labor Wars]], a struggle that latest for several years and took the lives of 33 union and non-union workers.{{ref|linder4}} The WFM initiated a series of strikes to combat the brutal working conditions and starvation wages. The defeat of these strikes led to Haywood's belief in "One Big Union" organized along industrial lines to bring broader [[working class]] support for labour struggles.{{fact}}
